metadata.title: Properties improvement of fly ash cenosphere modified cement pastes using nano silica

Properties Improvement of Fly Ash Cenosphere Modified Cement Pastes Using Nano Silica 1 Asad Hanif a, Pavithra Parthasarathy a, Hongyan Ma b, Tianyuan Fan a, Zongjin Li c* 2
a Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, The Hong Kong University of Science 3 and Technology, Clear Water Bay, Kowloon, Hong Kong, S.A.R. China 4 b Department of Civil, Architectural and Environmental Engineering, Missouri University of 5 Science and Technology, Rolla, MO, USA 6 c Institute of Applied Physics and Materials Engineering, University of Macau (UM), Taipa, 7 Macau, S.A.R, China 8
*Corresponding author; email address: zongjin@ust.hk, Phone:(+853)88224016, 9
Fax:(+853)88222454 10
Email addresses : ahanif@connect.ust.hk (A. Hanif); ppac@connect.ust.hk (P. Parthasarathy); 11 mahon@mst.edu (H. Ma); tfanaa@ust.hk (T. Fan); zongjin@ust.hk (Z. Li) 12
Abstract 13 In this study, the effect of nano silica (NS) on the properties of cement pastes incorporated with 14 of fly ash cenospheres (FACs) has been investigated. A fixed amount of 1 % NS was added to 15 cement pastes containing various proportions of FAC. It was found that NS was beneficial in 16 improving the mechanical strength of the FAC modified cement pastes. At the 7 – day age, the 17 strength increase for NS modified pastes was about 17 % as compared to pastes without NS. 18 However, the strength enhancement effect decreased with increasing age and FAC content. The 19 dense microstructure of the NS modified pastes compensated for the higher porosity associated 20 with FAC incorporation, leading to the reduced total porosity. With NS, there was better bonding 21 of the FAC particles in the matrix, due to the enhanced interface. The reduced Ca(OH)2 content 22 and partially consumed FAC spherical shells at the early age showed that NS increased the 23 pozzolanic activity of FAC in the cement pastes. 24
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
Keywords: Cement paste; Fly ash cenosphere; Nano silica; Microstructure; Thermal analysis; 25 Porosity; BET analysis 26
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED

sections.heading: 1. Introduction 27
sections.text:
The use of fly ash in cement-based composites as supplementary cementing material (SCM) has 28 gained significant consideration due to its beneficial effects on the modified composites [1–13]. 29 One important component of fly ashes is a minor but conspicuous fraction of cenospheres, 30 usually termed as Fly Ash Cenospheres (FACs), which are relatively larger in size (up to several 31 hundred microns), thin-walled and hollow spherical particles [14]. The chemical composition is 32 similar to typical fly ash (FA) because of their same origin, but the physical characteristics 33 (particle size, bulk density, morphology, and surface area) differ largely. Due to this reason the 34 properties of resulting composites incorporating FA and FAC may differ significantly because 35 of difference in pozzolanic activity and strength activity index [15]. FACs are considered as 36 suitable filler material for producing green lightweight binder pastes due to their origin (obtained 37 as waste residue from coal-fired power plants) [16], lightweight nature (bulk density up to 800 38 kg/m3) and partial reactivity [17,18]. However, the reactivity of the FACs in the cement 39 composites is limited due to their glassy surface, particle size and chemical composition. The 40 pozzolanic reaction is relatively slow, and only leads to adequate strength development only at 41 later ages [19,20]. Various methods have been tried, in the past years, to accelerate the strength 42 development in such composites, including mechanical treatment [21–25], high temperature 43 curing [26,27], alkali activation [28], and sulfate activation [29]. It has been found that these 44 methods are not only expensive and complex, but also potentially compromise the durability of 45 the resulting composites due to the alkali – silica reaction [30] and formation of large quantities 46 of ettringite [20]. 47
With the advancement and maturity of nanotechnology, the use of nano materials in cement and 48 concrete composites for improved properties has become an important research area in recent 49
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
years [31–34]. Among various nano-materials, nanosilica (NS) has been widely investigated due 50 to its beneficial effects on cement pastes and mortars, particularly the early age strength 51 development characteristics [35–45]. Haruehansapong et al [35] showed that utilizing NS in 52 cement mortars resulted in a homogeneous and densified microstructure as a result of the 53 increased pozzolanic activity. Moreover, reduction in calcium hydroxide (CH) crystals due to 54 growth of greater calcium silicate hydrate (CSH) has also been confirmed [36], and explains the 55 better strength characteristics at the early-age. The addition of only 0.25% NS was shown to 56 increase the 1 – day strength by 16% in NS modified cement pastes [46]. Such improvements in 57 the strength and microstructure characteristics are credited to the higher surface area of NS 58 which increase the pozzolanic activity by acting as centers for crystallization, resulting in the 59 formation of large idiomorphic crystals of Ca–Si composition, thus leading to denser 60 microstructure with reduced porosity and increased strength of the NS modified composites and 61 pastes [45,47,48]. NS has also been proven beneficial in improving the interface between the 62 paste matrix and filler material [47] thereby encouraging its use in cementitious pastes and 63 mortars. The use of NS can have certain drawbacks like reduced workability requiring greater 64 water content [41], possible agglomeration resulting in greater void space [48], and slower 65 hydration rate at the later ages of strength development [49]. Nevertheless, current research 66 appears very encouraging in using NS for improved properties of composites in construction. 67
A limited number of research has also been performed on fly ash concretes and mortars modified 68 by the addition of NS for improved properties, allowing high volumes of fly ash to be 69 incorporated, with enhanced strength development e.g. [2,20,40,50–52]. Li [20] evaluated the 70 characteristics of concrete (incorporating large amounts of fly ash) modified with NS and 71 compared these with concretes without NS. It was shown that NS significantly increased the 72
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
pozzolanic activity in fly ash concretes having 4% NS, with an increase of the 3 – day strength of 73 81%. Zhang and Islam [50] experimentally investigated the NS addition effects on hydration 74 properties and strength development in concrete containing 50 % fly ash, and found that using 2 % 75 of NS could increase the 3 – day and 7 – day strengths by 30 % and 25 %, respectively; however 76 there was not a significant change after the 28 – day age. Similar findings were pointed out by 77 Roychand et al [2] where it was emphasized that NS could improve the properties of fly ash 78 concrete compared to normal concrete. Moreover, after the 28 – day age, the hydration hindrance 79 by NS could be a critical reason for the lack of appreciable strength gain [40]. 80

sections.heading: 1.1. Research significance 81
sections.text:
Although, a few studies (as referenced above) have been undertaken on fly ash containing 82 cement-based composites, there have been no studies conducted that focused on the effects of 83 NS incorporation in pastes/composites containing FAC. The present study is conducted to fill 84 these research gaps. Evolution of compressive strength was determined for cement pastes 85 modified by FAC and NS, while in-depth study on the microstructure and hydration products 86 was done at various ages. Porosity and pore size distributions were also evaluated for a better 87 understanding of FAC/NS modified pastes. The study provides useful information for producing 88 high performance green, lightweight composites for use in construction. 89 2. Materials and Experimental Methods 90 2.1. Materials 91
Ordinary Portland cement (OPC; Type 52.5) from Hong Kong Green Island Cement Ltd, Fly 92 Ash Cenosphere (FAC) from Zhen Yang, Hebei China, and Nano Silica (NS) from Sigma – 93 Aldrich were used in this exploratory study. The OPC used had a specific gravity of 3.14 while 94 the bulk density of the FAC and NS were 720 kg/m3 and 50 kg/m3, respectively. The physical 95
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT
ED
characteristics of the FAC and NS employed in the study are tabulated in Table Error! 96 Reference source not found., while the elemental analysis (X- Ray Fluorescence Spectroscopy; 97 XRF) of the raw materials showing the amounts of various oxides is given in Table 2. It can be 98 seen from Table 1 that NS possesses very high surface area (200 m2/g; which is about 10 times 99 more than that of silica fume [53]) which is thought to enhance the pozzolanic activity in FAC 100 modified cement pastes just like it does so in ordinary pastes by acting as centers for 101 crystallization resulting in the formation of large idiomorphic crystals of Ca–Si composition [48]. 102 The silica content in the NS was higher than 99.9%. Figure 1 shows the crystal structure (peaks) 103 obtained from the X-ray Diffraction (XRD), and a polymorph crystal structure of cristobalite was 104 identified in FAC. The particle size analysis of the cement and FAC was done by laser 105 granulometry (using Coulter LS230) which showed that FAC particles were relatively larger in 106 size in comparison to cement particles, indicating the reactivity of the FAC particles (if any) can 107 be low in the pastes (Figure 2). The maximum size of the cement and FAC particles was found 108 as 100 µm and 300 µm, respectively. The morphological characteristics of the NS used in the 109 study from transmission electron microscopy (TEM), are shown in Figure 3. 110

2.2. Mixture proportioning and specimen preparation 122 The mixture proportions, incorporating different weight fractions of fly ash cenospheres (FACs), 123 used, are given in Table 3. FAC was used to replace cement in the mix in various dosages of 124 10 %, 20 %, and 30 %. The specified water to binder ratio in Table 3 represents the ratio of 125 weight of water to the weight of cement plus FAC. A Hobart mixer (10L capacity) was used for 126 preparing the paste mixtures. First, the cement and FAC were dry mixed thoroughly and after 127 water addition, mixing was further continued for 3 – 4 minutes. Nano silica (NS) was used in the 128 colloidal form. For the pastes containing NS, dry NS was weighed and then mixed (separately) in 129 the pre-determined quantity of mixing water (required for the paste). The NS was thoroughly 130 mixed by rigorous agitating in the water to avoid agglomeration and was further subjected to 131 ultra-sonication (for one hour) so that the visual appearance had no sign of any agglomerates. 132 Once the adequate mixing was achieved, it was further used in the paste preparation. 133 Transmission electron microscopic (TEM) image of NS particles dispersed in water after being 134 subjected to ultra-sonication is presented in Figure 3 which shows a good degree of dispersion of 135 nano particles in water, however, there are some agglomeration spots which are inevitable due to 136 the inherent properties of nano sized particles. From Figure 3 (a), the spherical morphology of 137 nano silica particle with a uniform size distribution in range of 10-15 nm can be observed. 138 Aggregate formation of nano silica found in the TEM image is due to the agglomeration of nano 139 silica particles. Further, the SAED pattern (Figure 3 (b)) shows the amorphous nature of NS 140 [54,55]. A poly-carboxylate based admixture (Grace ADVA 105) was also employed (0.2 % by 141 cement weight) to modify the paste viscosity so that the agglomeration of NS particles in the mix 142 could be significantly reduced. Once the mix was ready, it was cast into pre-oiled steel cubic 143 molds of size 50 mm x 50 mm x 50 mm. The molds were sealed using a plastic sheet. Molds 144
M AN
US
CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
were then placed under ambient conditions in the laboratory for a day, after which they were 145 opened and the specimens were moist cured in a room at 95% relative humidity and 25oC 146 temperature. Curing was prolonged till the compressive strength testing age which was 7, 28, 56, 147 and 90 days. For micro-structural, morphological and thermal analyses, the pastes were cast 148 separately in small plastic bags (250 ml volume) and cured under the same conditions as were 149 adopted for compressive strength specimens. Curing was continued till the desired testing age. 150

2.3. Experimental methods and procedures 152 2.3.1. Density and compressive strength 153 The density and compressive strength of the hardened specimen cubes was determined at various 154 ages. The compressive strength testing was done conforming to the standard practices of ASTM 155 C109 [56], where the loading rate was taken as 1.0 kN/sec. 156
2.3.2. Morphology and microstructure 157 The morphological and microstructural features were studied using various techniques. Scanning 158 Electron Microscopic (SEM) imaging was done for characterizing the hydration products and 159 pore structure, evaluating the interface between FAC and the paste matrix, and observing the 160
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
distribution of FACs in the matrix. Energy dispersive x-ray (EDX) detectors installed within the 161 SEM equipment further facilitated quantification of the hydration products by area mapping and 162 line scanning techniques. 163
2.3.3. Thermal analysis and phase identification/quantification 164 Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) was employed for determining the phase transformations 165 and weight changes with temperature. Moreover, the influence of NS and FAC on the degree of 166 reactivity was estimated by referring to the amount of free calcium hydroxide (CH) residing in 167 the dried pastes. For TGA, the samples were prepared by grinding the broken pieces from the 168 fractured specimens after compressive strength and subjected to heating in a top-open crucible 169 from 20 oC to 800 oC at a rate of 10 oC per minute. A TA Instruments Q5000 was used for TGA 170 measurements. The heating was done in a controlled nitrogen environment where the nitrogen 171 flow rate was set at 25 ml/minute. Prior to TGA testing, the specimen were dried at 80 oC for 6 172 hours to remove any free water. The corresponding values of weight loss and heat flow were 173 determined. From the TGA data, CH was calculated by computing the weight loss during 174 dehydroxylation and decarbonation. The dehydroxylation and decarbonation peaks were 175 precisely identified from the derivative thermogravimetric curves and corresponding molecular 176 weight ratios were used to determine CH [15,57–59]. 177
2.3.4. Porosity and pore size distributions 178 The pore volume characteristics in the pastes were studied by mercury intrusion porosimetry 179 (MIP) and nitrogen adsorption techniques. For the tests, the samples were broken down to 180 smaller sizes and pore water was removed by solvent replacement method. Ethanol solution was 181 used for this purpose. The specimens were immersed in ethanol solution and the solution was 182 replaced at few hours interval during first two days. Afterwards, the ethanol solution replacement 183
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
was done at one day interval until one week. Subsequently, the specimens were dried in a 184 vacuum desiccator. During MIP (Micromeritics AutoPore IV), the pressure was raised up to 414 185 MPa, which was the maximum capacity of the porosimeter (low pressure followed by high-186 pressure analysis). The stem volume used was higher than 25 % and lower than 90 % to ensure 187 reliable porosity results, as recommended by Micromertics. The mercury-concrete contact angle 188 was taken as 140o [60,61]. The Washburn equation [62] was used to determine relevant pore 189 diameters while the Katz-Thompson model [63] was employed to determine the permeability. 190 The specific surface area of the internal structure of the hydrated pastes was determined by the 191 nitrogen adsorption method. Moreover, it was also used to characterize the relatively smaller 192 pore sizes (less than 100 nm diameter) which could not be represented realistically by MIP. The 193 samples were outgassed at 90 oC for 120 minutes prior to subjecting them to nitrogen adsorption. 194 The model of Barrett, Joyner, and Halenda (BJH) [64], which employs monolayer adsorption and 195 capillary condensation theory, for determining the pore characteristics using the adsorption and 196 desorption isotherms, was used while the Brunauer, Emmet, and Teller (BET) theory [65] was 197 employed to estimate the specific surface and total pore area. 198 3. Results – Discussion and Analysis 199 3.1. Density and compressive strength 200
Figure 4 shows the results of saturated surface dry (SSD) density of the specimen (with and 201 without NS). It was found that for 10 wt% substitution of cement with FAC (F10), the 202 corresponding decrease of density was about 13 %, whereas with increasing FAC weight fraction 203 the density percentage decrease was reduced, e.g. for F20 it was 9.4 % (compared to F10) while 204 for F30, it was 7 % (compared to F20). It was also observed that the addition of NS slightly 205 increased the density of the specimens at all ages, and this increase was more apparent in nF10 206
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
and nF20, indicating that incorporating more FAC in the pastes may limit / restrict the hydration 207 process. For 30 wt% FAC content (nF30), the density was almost unchanged after 7-day whereas 208 the control paste specimen (F30) indicated no significant density change at all ages. 209
210 Figure 4 Density of hardened specimen at different ages 211
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
212
Figure 5 Compressive strength of hardened specimen cubes at various ages 213
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
The results of compression testing are shown in Figure 5 which represents average values of the 214 tested specimen (three specimens were tested at each age and the mean values were plotted. The 215 strength was found to decrease with decreasing density (due to FAC increasing amount) whereas 216 the NS addition increased it significantly at 7 and 28-day ages except specimen for 30 wt% FAC 217 (nF30) where the 28-day compressive strength was found similar to its counterpart (F30). At 7-218 day age, all the NS modified specimen showed 17 % higher strength than their counterparts 219 (FAC pastes without NS i.e. CM, F10, F20, and F30). After 28-day age, the increment was 220 minimal, whereas after 90 days, the strengths of paste specimen with and without NS were 221 almost similar except for nF10 where the strength was still 4.3% higher than F10. This showed 222 that NS is useful in increasing early-age strength. 10wt% of FAC was found the most suitable 223 weight fraction in effectively utilizing the benefits of NS. 224 3.2. Morphology and microstructure 225 SEM imaging and EDX analysis: Figure 6 shows the general morphological features of the 226 hardened paste specimen at 120 – day age. It is clearly shown that FAC incorporation led to the 227 increased porosity of the pastes. The increased porosity is due to two reasons; first, the spherical 228 nature of the FAC particles affects the packing and results in the inclusion of air voids within the 229 matrix, and second, the partial reactivity of the FAC particles which may result in FAC shell 230 consumption in the pozzolanic reaction, thus leaving behind the voids. Although, the porosity 231 seemed to increase with FAC addition, the use of NS showed beneficial effects in improving the 232 microstructure. SEM images taken at the same magnification clearly show dense and more 233 tightly packed matrix characteristics of NS incorporated pastes. The porosity results corroborated 234 the observations. It could also be seen, from the SEM imaging, that FAC modified cement pastes 235 had some amounts of unreacted and inert FAC particles as well along with the partially reacted 236
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
(consumed in pozzolanic reaction) particles. However, for the NS-FAC modified paste specimen, 237 a greater portion of reacted FAC particles could be seen. Further, the reaction products were also 238 seen inside of the FAC shell which was not the case for pastes modified with FAC only. Denser 239 and more uniform microstructure was also identified in the NS-FAC modified paste specimen. 240 Although the FAC particles showed selective reactivity which was identified from the partially 241 consumed spherical shell in the SEM imaging, with NS addition it was found that certain FAC 242 particles were consumed fully by taking part in the hydration and pozzolanic reactions. Complete 243 consumption of FAC shells was observed (in the NS-FAC modified pastes) at some locations, 244 and reaction products were identified, as shown in Figure 7. Further, ettringite crystals (needle 245 shape) were also found along with plate like crystals. Some cracking (crack width in nanometers) 246 was also seen in specimens containing NS (Figure 9) which is attributed to the higher shrinkage 247 owing to the presence of nano silica which resulted in greater pozzolanic activity. 248 Another important feature of the microstructure of the hardened specimens is the uniformity, 249 compactness, and denseness of the interface between the FAC particles and the binder matrix. It 250 is seen that NS is very advantageous in improving the interface properties. Figure 8 shows the 251 microstructure of the area surrounding the FAC particle, at 1-day age (Figure 8(a)) and 3-day age 252 (Figure 8 (b)). The presence of dense CSH crystal structure at the interface between FAC particle 253 and binder matrix could be seen (in the FAC-NS modified pastes) indicating that NS contributes 254 to the strength development, whereas in the pastes without NS, plate like crystals of CH and 255 needle shaped ettringite crystals are more pronounced. Another important aspect is the binding of 256 the FAC particle shell with the paste. At the higher magnification (Figure 8 (b)), it is observed 257 that the FAC particles are more tightly held in the paste matrix (in NS modified pastes). 258 However, in the pastes without NS, such dense microstructure is missing, rather at many points, 259
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
gap (a few microns) between the shell and matrix have been seen. The reason for such improved 260 properties in NS modified paste relates to the role of NS in accelerated pozzolanic reactivity [66]. 261 To further substantiate the microstructural features at the FAC-matrix interface, line scanning 262 EDX analysis was also done for FAC incorporated pastes (F20 and nF20). The quantification 263 results thus obtained are shown in (Figure 10). Based on the element composition analyses, the 264 NS effect on the interface between FAC and matrix can be examined. Higher Si/Ca ratio was 265 found for NS modified pastes as compared to pastes without NS. This is due to two reasons: first, 266 Si included in NS itself, and second, the formation of secondary hydrates due to pozzolanic 267 reactions of nano-silica with portlandite [67]. 268 It is also pertinent to mention another positive effect of NS on the pastes, i.e., the pore filling 269 effect. The EDX area mapping shown in Figure 11 shows how the NS particles fill the pores due 270 to their nano size. The mapping area of calcium and silicon elements compared with the 271 corresponding SEM image reveals that the consumption of FAC shell created voids or large 272 pores left after hydration of FAC particles which were later on filled by NS particles. However, 273 this is further verified by the porosity and pore volume characteristics presented in subsequent 274 sections. 275

3.3. Thermal analysis and phase identification/quantification 290 The TGA results at 3 – day age are shown in Figure 12 where the weight loss and derivative 291 thermogravimetric (DTG) curves are plotted on different y-axes. From the DTG curves in Figure 292 12, three main peaks are distinctly identified which correspond to the C-S-H dehydration (release 293 of water unbounded and bounded within the gel), ettringite and AFm between 80 oC and 200 oC, 294
dehydroxylation of Ca(OH)2 around 450 oC and decarbonation of CaCO3 around 650 oC. At all 295 ages, the TGA results showed similar weight loss trends which is why only a representative set 296 of curves at early age is shown here. The different segments of the TGA curves are marked on 297
Figure 12(a) in the dashed boxes. The temperatures at the dehydroxylation (calcium hydroxide 298 decomposition) and decarbonation (calcium carbonate decomposition) reactions were precisely 299 read from the DTG curves and corresponding weight loss was determined (from the relative 300 molecular weight ratios) to further calculate the CH contents. CH is consumed in pozzolanic 301 reactions thus increasing the C-S-H gel amounts in the hydration products. It follows that 302 reduced CH means greater pozzolanic activity. Figure 13 shows the amount of free CH residing 303 in the dried pastes at various ages, where the solid lines indicate FAC modified pastes without 304 NS incorporation whereas the same colored dashed lines represent FAC modified pastes with 305 added NS. CM and nCM are the control (reference) paste specimens containing no FAC. 306
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
Several important and meaningful deductions can be obtained from the Figure 13. First, the 307 pozzolanic reaction of FAC can be confirmed for all ages, which is indicated from the reduced 308 CH content for FAC containing pastes in relation to the control (CM). With the increasing FAC 309 amount and age, the difference increased, e.g. at 1-day the difference in CH amount between CM 310 and F10 was found to be less than 1 % whereas at 3-day, 7-day, and 90-day it was determined to 311 be 3 % (average). This indicates that increased degree of pozzolanic reactions take place with 312 aging. Similarly for F20 and F30, the average difference was observed as 15 % and 25%, 313 respectively (until 7-day age). The decreased CH content is a balance of three effects: first, the 314 incorporation of FAC diluted cement, which generates less CH when hydrated to the same 315 degree as the control paste; second, the effective water-to-cement ratio increases and FAC 316 particles can act as nucleation sites, which improve the degree of hydration of cement at a certain 317 age, releasing more CH; third, the pozzolanic reaction of FAC consumes CH. The second effect 318 is believed to be the reason why differences between CM and F10 are so small. 319 The NS addition further reduced the CH content in pastes. At the 1-day age, the FAC weight 320 fraction seemed to govern the reaction degree in FAC-NS modified pastes as the difference in 321 CH amounts of pastes was found as 2 %, 3 % and 6 % with 10 %, 20 %, and 30 % substitution of 322 cement with FAC. Surprisingly, there was about 4 % increase in CH amount of nCM over CM. 323 With the increasing age, it is seen that NS has been more effective later, as the difference in CH 324 amounts of pastes with and without NS increases. However, nF10 has shown the greatest 325 difference at 90-day age (about 15%) whereas it was ca. 8 % and 3 % for nF20 and nF30, 326 respectively. It suggests that 10 % weight substitution of cement by FAC is the most appropriate 327 if NS is to be used. Similar scenario was seen in compressive strength evaluation (Figure 5) 328 where at 90-day age, nF10 pastes still indicated some strength increase in relation to their 329
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
counterpart (F10). The trend of NS containing FAC pastes illustrate that at early ages (up to 7-330 day), NS was beneficial in increasing the pozzolanic reaction degree while later on the curves 331 tend to flatten out indicating the reduced activity. This was also observed in the compressive 332 strength results where the strength values after the 7-day age illustrate lower differences with 333 their corresponding counterparts (Figure 5). This agreement leads to conclude the advantageous 334 effects of NS in FAC modified pastes at early ages. 335
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
336
Figure 12 TGA weight loss and derivative thermogravimetric (DTG) curves, for FAC modified 337 pastes (a) without NS, and (b) with NS; (3-day age)338
M
AN

339
Figure 13 Amounts of free calcium hydroxide remaining in the paste after hydration 340
3.4. Porosity and pore size distributions 341 As cement-based materials are porous in nature, their resulting properties are influenced by the 342 porosity as well as the distribution of the pores (of different sizes). The porosity and pore size 343 distribution results obtained by nitrogen adsorption and mercury intrusion porosimetry (MIP) 344 techniques are summarized in Table 4. The total intrusion volume decreased with NS addition 345 except for 20 wt% of FAC where a slight increase was found which may be due to non-346 homogeneity of the specimen under testing. The pore size distribution curves from MIP (Figures 347 15 and 16) show that all pastes had a principally a unimodal distribution (i.e. only one maxima 348 peak). The NS addition did influence the porosity but not in a significant fashion due to the age 349 at which the testing was done. At 4 months age, only up to 2 % reduction in total porosity in 350 FAC modified pastes has been seen with the addition of NS. However, materials with even the 351 same porosity can perform completely differently because of size and dispersal of pores, in the 352
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
matrix [68]. The critical pore diameter (dc) and threshold pore diameter (dth) are shifted towards 353 left (lower pore size range) on the log differential and cumulative porosity plot, respectively. dc is 354 determined from the highest point of log differential curve whereas dth is determined from the 355 slope of cumulative porosity curve [60]. Addition of NS tends to shift these from macro-pore 356 zone to meso-pore zone thus making the pore structure finer. dc value of 0.0626 µm (average) 357 was determined for FAC pastes whereas for NS modified FAC pastes it was found as 0.0504 µm. 358 However, the difference is not significant due to the testing age. As dc represents the maximum 359 continuous pore size i.e. it is the most frequently occurring pore size in interconnected pores 360 [68], it can be said that NS modified pastes have lower transmissivity (permeability). Also, from 361 the well-known strength-porosity relationships [69] combined with the compressive strength 362 results (Figure 5), the small differences observed at 120-days age are justifiable. 363 Bulk density and apparent (skeletal) density values were also obtained from MIP which are 364 reported in Table 4. All the NS containing pastes showed higher bulk density except for nF20 365 where an increase of about 4% was determined which can be attributed to non-homogeneity. A 366 further analysis of the difference in bulk density and apparent (skeletal) density may provide 367 useful insights into the effects of FAC and NS incorporation in the pastes. It is found that on 368 average, 7 % air void content was introduced within the pastes due to additional 10 wt% addition 369 of FAC while NS addition (1 %) increased the solid phase content in the pastes by 1.5 %. In the 370 solid phase, CSH is likely to be present in greater quantity as verified from the TGA analyses 371 (reduced CH due to reaction with amorphous silica). The higher density corresponds to higher 372 mechanical strength due to the higher density of CSH [70] as compared to other hydration 373 products. This further substantiates that FAC incorporation leads to increased air void and NS 374 improves the mechanical properties. 375
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
In order to further study the pore structure, nitrogen adsorption methods were employed and 376 BET and BJH theories were used for characterization. The nitrogen adsorption isotherms are 377 plotted in Figure 14. The pore volume data obtained by nitrogen adsorption can also be 378 converted to porosity (at the sub-micrometer level) by using the bulk density obtained by MIP. 379 According to the IUPAC classification, all the pastes display a physiosorption isotherm of Type 380 IV and a hysteresis loop type H1 (which correspond to meso-porous and macro-porous materials) 381 which are linked to capillary condensation occurring in the mesopores, and the “limiting uptake 382 over higher range of relative pressure” (Ps/Po) [71]. The initial linear part of the isotherm (0.05 ≤ 383 P/Po ≤ 0.35) indicates that the BET theory is applicable [72]. It could be seen that NS addition 384 led to decreased total adsorption of nitrogen gas which is attributed to the ability of NS in filling 385 the pores and formation of denser reaction products. Moreover, the adsorption increased with 386 increase of FAC weight fraction which is due to the hollow nature of the FAC particles. The 387 partly consumed shells of FACs allowed more gas to adsorb thus increasing the total adsorption. 388 However, with NS addition a rather different result was obtained. The pore classification 389 (according to their sizes) and corresponding quantification (based on the volume percentage can 390 also been done using the BJH adsorption data. The classification of pores has been argued and 391 contradictory in the literature, however, in the current study the classification of adopted by 392 Aligizaki [68] and Mindess et al [73] has been employed. Further, in order to compare the 393 volume fraction of different pores, a single classification should be used consistently throughout, 394 which may help in establishing the relationships and in studying the effects of different 395 parameters on the respective specimens. 396 The volume percentage of the gel pores in NS incorporated pastes was found to be higher than 397 their corresponding counterparts, indicating a greater formation of reaction products. Such 398
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
observation was also seen in the microstructural investigations where it was found that NS 399 accelerated the pozzolanic activity of FAC particles (Figure 7). Also, the macro-pores volume 400 fraction was also reduced due to NS addition. Two different effects on the macro-porosity of the 401 resulting pastes can be associated with NS addition; first, increase of NS increases the pozzolanic 402 activity, and second, the inefficient dispersion leading to formation of flocculates that may not 403 act as fillers rather push back the cement particles thereby increasing the void space leading to 404 increased macro-porosity [49,74]. The effects on the macro-porosity further endorses the 405 efficient dispersion of NS particles, however, the reference sample does not represent the whole 406 specimen and such conclusion cannot be drawn solely on these results. The cumulative porosity 407 indicated that total porosity at sub-micrometer level reduces with NS addition in FAC modified 408 pastes. However, nCM gave rather inconsistent results which may be due to the inherent 409 limitations and drawbacks of nitrogen adsorption methods, to be employed in hydrated cement 410 pastes, as well as the possible agglomeration and non – uniform distribution of NS. 411 In Figure 14, the N2-adsorption includes a big contribution from capillary pores (up to 100 nm). 412 It is reduced by NS, because an improved degree of hydration results in a lower porosity. 413 Another consequence of improved degree of hydration is a larger specific surface area due to a 414 larger amount of hydrates gel, which can be determined from the N2-adsorption isotherms based 415 on the BET theory (using only low relative pressure section of the isotherm). The determined 416 specific surface areas have been included in Table 4. Comparing the data of NS-free pastes and 417 NS-incorporated pastes, it is clear that NS increases the specific surface area and gel pore 418 volume fraction in all pores, showing an improved degree of hydration. 419 The BET surface areas obtained were found as 9.86 m2/g – 23.18 m2/g for FAC incorporated 420 pastes without NS addition while for their counterparts containing NS, these values were 421
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
determined as 12.59 m2/g – 18.36 m2/g. The BET surface area values determined in this study 422 are smaller than the values reported in the published literature on ordinary cement pastes [75–78] 423 but similar to those determined by Odler [75]. The difference in such values is due to the raw 424 materials (FAC and NS) as well as the drying methodology adopted as pre-treatment of 425 specimens for pore water removal. The value of constant ‘C’ in the BET Equation is affected by 426 the specimen drying method [68,72]. This may be one of the reason for lower BET values 427 obtained in this paper. Also, the BET tests in this study were done at STP (Standard Temperature 428 and Pressure) conditions. The lower BETN2 values obtained in this study may also be attributed 429 to low temperature and short equilibrium time employed [76,77,79]. 430 It is pertinent to mention that these values depend upon multiple factors like water/cement ratio, 431 curing conditions, testing age, testing parameters as well as the specimens preparation method 432 (the method by which the water is removed from the pore system) [75]. Although, Odler [75] 433 reported such varying BET surface area values, it was also concluded in the study that “the 434 BETN2 values do not represent the total surface area of C-S-H-based materials”. Therefore, 435 although the surface area gives indication about the hydration degree, still it may not be used to 436 establish absolute values due to the possibility of generating erroneous results. It was also 437 corroborated by the work of Nunes et al [39]. 438

4. Conclusions 451 A comprehensive and thorough study on cement pastes modified with various proportions of fly 452 ash cenosphere (FAC) and 1% nano silica (NS) was conducted to investigate the beneficial 453 effects of NS in producing green lightweight binders for construction applications. Cement 454 pastes were prepared with varying FAC weight fractions (10 %, 20 %, and 30 %) and a fixed 455 water to cementing materials ratio of 0.30. Two sets of pastes were studied for the analysis; one 456 without NS and one with 1 % of added NS. The resulting pastes were tested for mechanical 457 strength at different ages and further examined as to their microstructure and hydration products. 458 Following conclusions are drawn from the investigation: 459
1. The use of FAC in cement pastes can reduce the density of the resulting composite (due 460 to its lightweight nature) without significant strength loss (due to its pozzolanic effect). 461 10 % cement replacement (by weight) by FAC was found to be the optimal value in this 462 study. 463 2. A more refined, denser, uniform, and compact microstructure was achieved with NS 464 addition. Although a significant proportion of the FAC particles was partly consumed in 465 the NS containing cement pastes, the particles with intact shells showed much better 466 bonding and a denser microstructure at the interface. 467 3. The porosity was reduced in the pastes with NS addition. However, after 4 months of age, 468 the difference in porosity was minimal. Moreover, NS contributed towards the increased 469 gel pores. 470 4. The reasons for properties improvement primarily arise from the pore filling effect and 471 accelerated pozzolanic reaction of NS particles. Lower calcium hydroxide amounts 472
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
remaining in the pastes and increased formation of CSH contributed largely to the 473 improved properties. 474

The 477 authors also gratefully acknowledge the technical support for BET analysis and particle 478 granulometry provided by Advanced Engineering Manufacturing Facility (AEMF) at HKUST. 479 The authors would also thank Ms. S. 25% NS was shown to 56 increase the 1 – day strength by 16% in NS modified cement pastes [46].

Such improvements in 57 the strength and microstructure characteristics are credited to the higher surface area of NS 58 which increase the pozzolanic activity by acting as centers for crystallization, resulting in the 59 formation of large idiomorphic crystals of Ca–Si composition, thus leading to denser 60 microstructure with reduced porosity and increased strength of the NS modified composites and 61 pastes [45,47,48].

NS has also been proven beneficial in improving the interface between the 62 paste matrix and filler material [47] thereby encouraging its use in cementitious pastes and 63 mortars.

The use of NS can have certain drawbacks like reduced workability requiring greater 64 water content [41], possible agglomeration resulting in greater void space [48], and slower 65 hydration rate at the later ages of strength development [49].

metadata.abstractText: 13 In this study, the effect of nano silica (NS) on the properties of cement pastes incorporated with 14 of fly ash cenospheres (FACs) has been investigated. A fixed amount of 1 % NS was added to 15 cement pastes containing various proportions of FAC. It was found that NS was beneficial in 16 improving the mechanical strength of the FAC modified cement pastes. At the 7 – day age, the 17 strength increase for NS modified pastes was about 17 % as compared to pastes without NS. 18 However, the strength enhancement effect decreased with increasing age and FAC content. The 19 dense microstructure of the NS modified pastes compensated for the higher porosity associated 20 with FAC incorporation, leading to the reduced total porosity. With NS, there was better bonding 21 of the FAC particles in the matrix, due to the enhanced interface. The reduced Ca(OH)2 content 22 and partially consumed FAC spherical shells at the early age showed that NS increased the 23 pozzolanic activity of FAC in the cement pastes. 24 M AN US CR IP T AC CE PT ED ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 2
metadata.creator: Elsevier
